awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Molecular Biology and Genetics of Cell Signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Cornell University, located in Ithaca, NY, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020- 2022. It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities or are from an under-represented group, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Assessment of the program will be done through the online SALG URSSA tool. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths.

The goal of this program is to provide a formative research experience for talented undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented and disadvantaged groups, that will motivate them to pursue a career in research, help them to be competitive for admission to research intensive graduate programs, and increase their success in these programs. The research focus is in the area of molecular signaling, a process that is fundamental to almost every cellular event. Training faculty are selected from various departments across the campus based on their research interests and their commitment to mentoring undergraduate research. In addition to conducting research in one of the participating labs, weekly REU group meetings with the program directors and various workshops provide students with a broad view of the signaling field in the general area of molecular sciences, opportunities to improve their communication skills, information about graduate school and careers in science, and awareness of responsible conduct of research. Students are also required to take pre- and post-program surveys for program assessment purposes. Students entering their sophomore, junior, or senior years, and majoring in the life sciences are encouraged to apply. Preference will be given to students with strong interest in gaining research experience in preparation for graduate study. Details on the application process, participating mentors and other information about the program are available by visiting https://mbg.cornell.edu/undergraduate/summer-research-experience/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Kelly Liu at JL53@cornell.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Tim Huffaker at tch4@cornell.edu). This award is supported by the Department of Defense ASSURE program thru a partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this REU program was to provide a supportive environment where students from institutions that do not provide significant research opportunities could come to Cornell University to conduct cutting-edge research, discover if they have a passion for research, and make informed decisions regarding graduate school and careers in modern biological sciences.

 

Between 2017 and 2024, with a gap in 2020 due to the pandemic, the program supported a total of 73 REU students. The impact of the program was further increased by the additional 8 undergraduates who were funded by other mechanisms but participated fully in all aspects of this REU program. Among past participants, more than 45% were first-generation college students, and more than 70% came from small non-PhD granting colleges, including community colleges.

The research focus of this program was in the field of molecular signaling, a process that is fundamental to almost every cellular event. The more than 20 participating faculty all conducted basic, curiosity-driven research in the general area of molecular signaling. During the 10-week summer program, each REU student, through their individual research projects that were guided by their respective faculty and lab mentors, delved into a particular area of molecular signaling. In addition to research, REU students attended weekly scientific talks that allowed them to have an appreciation of the broader signaling field. REU students were also introduced to various facilities and services available to them at Cornell University through orientation activities at the beginning of the program. Throughout the summer, REU students attended workshops on lab safety, research ethics, careers beyond the PhD, leadership and teamwork, as well as a number of other career development workshops that allowed them to improve their communication skills, and that provided information about graduate school and graduate fellowships. At the end of the program, each REU student gave a poster presentation and a 10 min talk. Multiple REU students attended and presented their work from the REU program at national or local research conferences after the end of the program. Many of them received outstanding presentation awards. Multiple REU students also co-authored papers published in top tier research journals based on research they conducted in our REU program. Several students subsequently received prestigious awards, such as the Goldwater Scholarship and the HHMI Gilliam Fellowship for Advanced Study. Details on these as well as the presentation and publication records of the REU students can be found at: https://cals.cornell.edu/molecular-biology-genetics/academics/undergraduate/summer-research-experience-undergraduates-reu-program/summer-reu-outcomes.

 

Post-program student surveys showed that, as a result of their research experiences in our program, 100% of the students reported that they had a good to great gain in their confidence to do research and in understanding what everyday research is like, and more than 90% said that their REU research experience prepared them for graduate school. Tracking of past REU students shows that 88% of those who have graduated are currently enrolled or were enrolled in graduate programs (PhD or MS) in top research institutions, such as Baylor College of Medicine, Cornell University, Johns Hopkins University, Northwestern University, Stanford University, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, University of Pennsylvania, University of Washington at St. Louis, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Yale University, among others, or are pursuing STEM-related careers.

 

In summary, the MBG-REU program at Cornell University has been successful in attracting students and providing them with cutting-edge research experiences in the molecular biosciences. Through these experiences, the students have gained confidence in research and become better prepared for graduate school as well as for future research careers in academia or industry.
